articles.title: The EU supports vulnerable women through projects in 10 local communities in BiH
articles.summary: The European Union has awarded 165,000 euros in non-refundable funds for projects to empower vulnerable women in 10 local communities in BiH, with the aim of strengthening social protection and combating violence.
articles.content:
The European Union has awarded 165,000 euros in non-refundable funds for projects to empower vulnerable women in 10 local communities in BiH, with the aim of strengthening social protection and combating violence.

Bihać, (Fena) – The European Union has awarded 165,000 euros in non-refundable funds to civil society organizations in ten municipalities and cities in BiH, with the aim of strengthening social protection, economic empowerment of women and combating gender-based violence.

The contracts were signed in Bihać, and organizations from Bihać, Gacko, Tuzla, Vlasenica, Bijeljina, Derventa, Novi Grad, Olovo, Sapna and Gradiška will receive the funds. The projects are aimed at improving the position of women who face multiple forms of vulnerability.

Head of the EU Office in Banja Luka Biljana Barović emphasized that gender equality and the empowerment of women are key EU values, and recalled the recently launched program worth 7.5 million euros to strengthen institutional responses to violence against women.

The project “Providing assistance to vulnerable women and developing an integrated social protection program”, worth 550,000 euros, is being implemented by the association “Žene s Une” in partnership with ASB.

Head of the European Union Office in Banja Luka Biljana Barović emphasized that gender equality and the empowerment of women are key values of the European Union, but also an important segment of Bosnia and Herzegovina’s European path.

“Too many women in Bosnia and Herzegovina still face discrimination, poverty and violence, often without adequate institutional support. This must change. Through this project, we support local efforts to strengthen the social protection of women, which is in line with our broader support, including the recently launched program worth 7.5 million euros to improve institutional responses to gender-based violence,” said Barović, stressing that joint action is crucial for a safer and more economically stable environment for women.

Mayor of Bihać Elvedin Sedić highlighted the importance of social responsibility and support for women, stating that such projects send a clear message that women are not alone. (24.12.)
articles.reasoning: The article reports on the European Union providing significant non-refundable funds to empower vulnerable women across multiple communities in Bosnia and Herzegovina, aiming to strengthen social protection and combat gender-based violence. This represents a meaningful, broad impact on human rights and gender equality with clear details on the funding, scope, and intended outcomes.

articles.title: The Tomorrow Club aims to support and mentor young writers amid polarity and tech-driven chaos
articles.summary: “The youth should never believe that history is written only by the victors, or that it can be permanently manipulated through narrative wars.”
articles.content:
Established in 1917, Tomorrow Club was envisioned by members of PEN International as a space to connect young writers with other members of the community to facilitate mentorship and foster solidarity.

In an email interview with Global Voices, PEN International board member Ege Dündar highlighted the continuing relevance of the Tomorrow Club. “We don’t listen to young voices enough who have urgent and unifying messages in concern for their future to tell us,” Dündar said, and added the following.

We know little about the experiences and stories of peers in other parts of the world, let alone those nearby with different views. We hope these efforts will open windows of personal experiences for discovery and learning about ‘distant’ countries and issues, in fact or fiction, at a human level.

This was echoed by Aung, regional editor from Myanmar and steering representative for Asia at PEN International’s Young Writers Committee. “In many parts of Asia, censorship shapes what we can say and what we can read. It is frighteningly easy to silence a voice, to shut someone’s mouth.”

Aung presented the Asia focus of the Tomorrow Club, whose latest edition featured 30 young voices under 35 years old from 20 countries. Aung shared the themes explored in their selection.

I am always eager to listen — to hear directly from real people. I am hungry for their stories. Through this focus on regional voices, I’ve had the chance to listen to my neighbours, to discover their different perspectives and the realities of their societies. Despite our differences, we never bow. We never surrender. Across Asia, people share a profound love for independence and equality. Whenever we sense injustice or imbalance, we rise and fight back.

In an email interview with this author, Aung reiterated their appeal to fellow young writers in the region. “The youth should never believe that history is written only by the victors, or that it can be permanently manipulated through narrative wars.”

Some of the writers featured from Asia included Amanda Socorro Lacaba Echanis, a political prisoner from the Philippines. An excerpt from her prison letter.

These past days, I admit that there is a heaviness in my heart. Memory has a way of bringing back the pain that we thought had already gone or we’d already forgotten. But beyond the pain, emerge the courage and voice we thought we didn’t have.

Theodore Pham wrote about the challenges faced by an activist working to protect Vietnam’s civil society space.

…the level of secrecy can still be high and draining even if only from a convenience perspective. Many of my friends outside the NGO world have not dealt with jobs that require hiding one's face and real name from colleagues.

Mayyu Ali poignantly tackled the uprootedness of the Rohingya people, who remain stateless as Myanmar continues to deny them as an ethnic minority. Millions were forced to flee Myanmar and have sought asylum in neighboring countries.

When a new-born comes into the world, the midwife carefully places the umbilical cord and placenta in the Hanri, a graceful terracotta pot – this is the Rohingya tradition. A family member, often the father or grandfather reverently lays the pot to rest in the Earth

Writer and filmmaker Sai Nyan Linn Sett narrated the difficulties encountered by young Myanmar citizens who fled to Thailand after the 2021 coup.

For young Myanmar artists who have escaped abroad, they face challenges in the form of getting legal status for residence, the scarcity of employment opportunities for most immigrants, exploitation due to the lack of legal protections such as a work visa, and so on. When the Thai border guard force catches them, they transfer the detainees back to the Myanmar army and these draft dodger youths are forced to become the new recruits of the military. And then they are sent to the frontline after just a few months of training and the youths who barely have any military training become cannon fodder at the frontline.

Merry’s account of her family’s escape from Myanmar to Thailand was turned into a brief video animation.

Reflecting on the Tomorrow Club’s work, Dündar advocated for additional initiatives to support young writers and artists.

Beyond our project, collectively as young voices speaking up for their future across borders, we need more support from media, foundations and institutions to commit funds and opportunities for young people to create platforms and connect over telling their stories, sharing experiences across borders. They need support however small to enhance their constructive projects so they can keep reflecting on their communities and connect the increasingly fractured society around them while simultaneously encouraging and educating the international community about contexts they experience. Contexts often left out from the West-oriented lenses on our news and popular culture in Europe for example.

Dündar noted the power of solidarity and expressed support for persecuted writers.

Things like writing support letters builds community with a sense of sustained solidarity and care around shared values. It personalizes a political context and in a way, makes a direct connection and thereby the overall struggle more tangible. You may not be able to do much to get rid of an dictator or authoritarian regime, but you may be able to connect with and support one young life struggling for their basic universal rights against that regime, and you may be able to affect change for the better too.

Finally, Dündar enumerated some of the plans of the Tomorrow Club, including the promotion of their advocacy in schools.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights the Tomorrow Club's efforts to support and mentor young writers across Asia, many facing censorship and persecution, thereby promoting freedom of expression, solidarity, and human rights. It focuses on a meaningful initiative with broad significance for young voices in repressive contexts, providing detailed examples and plans for advocacy.
articles.personality_title: Tomorrow Club supports young writers facing censorship across Asia
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The Tomorrow Club was created in 1917 by PEN International to connect young writers worldwide. It aims to help young people share their stories and support each other, especially in places where speaking freely can be dangerous.

**What happened** – The club recently featured 30 young writers from 20 Asian countries. Many of these writers face censorship, political struggles, or persecution. Through the club, they share personal stories about fighting for freedom, facing prison, or escaping conflict. Examples include a political prisoner from the Philippines, activists in Vietnam, and refugees from Myanmar.

**Impact** – This project gives a voice to young people whose stories are often hidden or silenced. By sharing these experiences, the club helps others understand difficult situations in different countries. It also builds a sense of community and support among young writers who face similar challenges.

**What's next step** – The Tomorrow Club plans to expand its work by promoting writing and advocacy in schools and encouraging more support from media and institutions. They want to create more opportunities for young writers to connect and share their stories globally.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The Tomorrow Club helps young Asian writers overcome censorship and connect through storytelling, promoting freedom and solidarity in difficult times.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Le club a récemment réuni 30 jeunes écrivains de 20 pays asiatiques. Beaucoup d'entre eux font face à la censure, à des luttes politiques ou à des persécutions. **Résumé en une phrase** – Le Tomorrow Club aide les jeunes écrivains asiatiques à surmonter la censure et à se connecter par leurs récits, promouvant liberté et solidarité en temps difficiles.

articles.title: Zelensky hails 'new ideas' on peace after talks with US envoys
articles.summary: Ukraine's leader gives an upbeat assessment after discussing the plan with Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner.
articles.content:
Zelensky hails 'new ideas' on peace after talks with US envoys

6 hours ago Share Save Vanessa Buschschlüter and Jaroslav Lukiv Share Save

EPA

Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky has given a positive assessment of a conversation he had with US envoys on how to end the Russia-Ukraine war. Zelensky said Thursday's call with Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner, which lasted nearly an hour, had yielded "new ideas in terms of formats, meetings, and... timing on how to bring a real peace closer". He spoke a day after giving details of an updated 20-point peace plan, agreed by US and Ukrainian envoys in Florida. Zelensky said he had asked Witkoff and Kushner to pass along Christmas greetings to US President Donald Trump "and the entire Trump family". The Kremlin said it was analysing proposals brought back from the US by a Russian envoy.

Trump and his envoys have been holding talks with both Ukraine and Russia in an effort to reach a deal to end the war which was started by Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022. There appears to have been some progress in recent days with Ukraine's president praising the "good ideas" put forward by Witkoff and Trump's son-in-law Kushner. Zelensky said it had been an "active day" for his country's diplomacy, as he went into details with the US envoys. He conceded that there was still "work to be done on sensitive issues" but added that "together with the American team, we understand how to put all of this in place". Zelensky added that Ukraine's top negotiator Rustem Umerov, the country's top security official, "will continue discussions with the American team". The 20-point peace plan agreed by the US and Ukraine is seen as an update to the initial draft prepared by Witkoff several weeks ago. That draft was widely seen as heavily geared towards Russia's maximalist pre-invasion demands, which Kyiv and its European said meant the de facto capitulation of Ukraine. Describing the updated proposal on Wednesday, Zelensky had said it offered Russia the potential withdrawal of Ukrainian troops from the east and the creation of a demilitarised zone in their place. He said the plan now included security guarantees from the US, Nato and Europeans for a co-ordinated military response if Russia invaded Ukraine again. On the key question of Ukraine's industrial eastern Donetsk region, Zelensky said a "free economic zone" was a potential option. Any area that Ukrainian troops pulled out of would have to be policed by Ukraine, he stressed. Moscow currently controls about 75% of the Donetsk region, and some 99% of the neighbouring Luhansk. They are collectively known as Donbas. Zelensky has been under heavy pressure from Trump to cede all of Donbas to Russia during ongoing Washington-led peace negotiations. The Ukrainian leader has so far rejected any territorial concessions, and instead demanded iron-clad security guarantees for Ukraine in any potential settlement. Russian President Vladimir Putin has repeatedly warned that Ukrainian troops must leave Donbas or Russia will seize it.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on promising diplomatic progress toward peace in the Russia-Ukraine war, which has broad significance for millions affected by the conflict. It details new peace proposals and ongoing negotiations, indicating potential steps toward ending hostilities and securing safety and sovereignty for Ukraine. The focus is clear and provides substantive context on the peace plan and diplomatic efforts.
articles.personality_title: Ukraine and US envoys explore new ideas to advance peace talks
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The war between Russia and Ukraine started in February 2022 when Russia launched a large invasion. Since then, many efforts have been made to find a way to stop the fighting and bring peace.

**What happened** – Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky spoke with two US envoys, Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner, for nearly an hour. They discussed new ideas about how to hold meetings and set times to bring peace closer. This happened after the US and Ukraine agreed on an updated 20-point peace plan. Zelensky also asked the envoys to send Christmas greetings to former US President Donald Trump and his family.

**Impact** – This is important because the peace plan offers ways to reduce fighting, like creating a demilitarized zone in eastern Ukraine and security guarantees from the US, NATO, and Europe if Russia attacks again. It shows progress in talks, even though some issues still need work. The plan aims to protect Ukraine’s control over its land while trying to find a peaceful solution.

**What’s next step** – Ukraine’s top negotiator, Rustem Umerov, will continue talking with the American team to work out the details. Meanwhile, Russia is reviewing the new proposals. The results of these talks could influence whether the war moves toward an end.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Ukraine and US envoys have shared new ideas and updated plans that could bring the countries closer to peace after years of conflict.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’Ukraine et les envoyés américains explorent de nouvelles idées pour avancer vers la paix
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La guerre entre la Russie et l’Ukraine a commencé en février 2022 avec une grande invasion russe. Depuis, de nombreux efforts sont faits pour arrêter les combats et apporter la paix.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le président ukrainien Volodymyr Zelensky a parlé près d’une heure avec deux envoyés américains, Steve Witkoff et Jared Kushner. Ils ont discuté de nouvelles idées pour organiser des réunions et fixer des dates afin d’avancer vers la paix. Cela fait suite à un plan de paix mis à jour en 20 points, accepté par les États-Unis et l’Ukraine. Zelensky a aussi demandé aux envoyés de transmettre ses vœux de Noël à l’ancien président américain Donald Trump et à sa famille.

**Impact** – C’est important car ce plan propose des moyens pour réduire les combats, comme créer une zone démilitarisée dans l’est de l’Ukraine et des garanties de sécurité des États-Unis, de l’OTAN et de l’Europe si la Russie attaque encore. Cela montre des progrès dans les discussions, même si des points doivent encore être réglés. Le plan vise à protéger le contrôle de l’Ukraine sur son territoire tout en cherchant une solution pacifique.

**Prochaine étape** – Le principal négociateur ukrainien, Rustem Umerov, continuera les discussions avec l’équipe américaine pour finaliser les détails. Pendant ce temps, la Russie analyse les nouvelles propositions. Ces discussions pourraient influencer la fin possible du conflit.

**Résumé en une phrase** – L’Ukraine et les envoyés américains ont partagé de nouvelles idées et des plans mis à jour qui pourraient rapprocher les pays de la paix après des années de guerre.
articles.personality_title_es: Ucrania y enviados de EE.UU. exploran nuevas ideas para avanzar en las conversaciones de paz
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La guerra entre Rusia y Ucrania comenzó en febrero de 2022 con una gran invasión rusa. Desde entonces, se han hecho muchos esfuerzos para detener los combates y lograr la paz.

**Qué pasó** – El presidente ucraniano Volodymyr Zelensky habló casi una hora con dos enviados estadounidenses, Steve Witkoff y Jared Kushner. Hablaron sobre nuevas ideas para organizar reuniones y fijar tiempos para acercar la paz. Esto ocurrió después de que EE.UU. y Ucrania acordaran un plan de paz actualizado con 20 puntos. Zelensky también pidió que enviaran saludos navideños al expresidente Donald Trump y su familia.

**Impacto** – Esto es importante porque el plan de paz ofrece formas de reducir la lucha, como crear una zona desmilitarizada en el este de Ucrania y garantías de seguridad de EE.UU., la OTAN y Europa si Rusia ataca nuevamente. Muestra avances en las conversaciones, aunque aún hay temas por resolver. El plan busca proteger el control de Ucrania sobre su territorio mientras se intenta una solución pacífica.

**Próximo paso** – El principal negociador de Ucrania, Rustem Umerov, continuará las conversaciones con el equipo estadounidense para definir los detalles. Mientras tanto, Rusia está revisando las nuevas propuestas. Estas conversaciones podrían influir en si la guerra se acerca a su fin.

**Frase clave** – Ucrania y enviados de EE.UU. compartieron nuevas ideas y planes actualizados que podrían acercar a los países a la paz tras años de conflicto.
